meanings.definition: To crow louder or more forcefully than someone else.
meanings.sent1: The rooster tried to outcrow the other roosters in the morning.
meanings.sent2: He always wants to outcrow his friends when they play games.
meanings.sent3: The little bird tried to outcrow the big rooster, but it just made everyone laugh.
meanings.sent4: Her laughter outcrowed the noise of the party, filling the room with joy.
meanings.sent5: The thunderstorm seemed to outcrow the chirping of the birds, announcing its arrival.

meanings.sent1: She would often outcrow about her achievements to anyone who would listen.
meanings.sent2: He tends to outcrow about his possessions whenever he gets the chance.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to outcrow about catching a mouse, but the mouse had actually escaped.
meanings.sent4: His voice outcrowed all others in the room, drawing attention to his stories.
meanings.sent5: The wind seemed to outcrow the trees, boasting its strength as it swayed them.

meanings.sent1: The outcrow of the rooster woke up the entire farm.
meanings.sent2: The outcrow of the peacock echoed through the valley.
meanings.sent3: The outcrow of the crow startled the squirrel, making it drop its nut.
meanings.sent4: The outcrow of the turkey could be heard from miles away.
meanings.sent5: The outcrow of the goose was so loud, it drowned out all other sounds in the meadow.
